nodes.text: Major infrastructure projects systematically exhibit cost underestimates and benefit overestimates that cause large economic risk and poor project selection
Major infrastructure projects have long planning horizons, complex interfaces, non-standard technology, multi-actor decision making, scope changes, and inadequate contingency for unplanned events

Empirical evidence: transportation projects (N=258) show average cost overruns of 44.7% for rail, 33.8% for bridges/tunnels, and 20.4% for roads; 9 out of 10 projects have cost overrun and overruns persist over 70 years

Empirical evidence: travel demand forecasts (N=208) show rail passenger traffic on average 51.4% lower than forecast (bias), road traffic forecasts less biased but with large errors; inaccuracy persists over 30 years
Cost-benefit analyses based on biased cost and demand forecasts are misleading and unreliable for major infrastructure decision making
Technical explanations (imperfect methods, data, honest mistakes) are rejected because forecast errors are systematically biased and have not decreased over time despite methodological improvements
Psychological explanations (planning fallacy, optimism bias) partly fit the bias but cannot alone explain persistent, profession-wide biased forecasts that do not improve with learning

Political-economic explanation: strategic misrepresentation (deliberate underestimation of costs and overestimation of benefits) caused by agency problems and competition for funds accounts well for the systematic bias
Survival of the un-fittest mechanism: projects that are made to look best on paper (via biased forecasts) are more likely to be approved but become the worst performers in reality

Method recommended: apply the outside view using reference class forecasting (identify comparable projects, establish distribution of outcomes, position the project in that distribution) to reduce bias
Result: reference class forecasting has been used in practice (e.g., Edinburgh Tram, Crossrail) and produces more realistic adjusted cost estimates and contingency uplifts

Governance reforms required: transparency, independent review, benchmarking, accountability (public and market), financial responsibility sharing, peer review, and legal/professional sanctions to change incentives and curb misrepresentation

Conclusion: rapidly increasing stimulus spending combined with a shift to emerging economies and rising use of ICT in projects heightens the risk of large financial and economic disasters unless methods and governance are improved
